s.text: participated in the design of the study, carried out the immunofluorescence stainings, interpreted the data and wrote the manuscript.

In type 1 diabetes, it has been shown that inflammatory cytokines play a central role in the destruction of insulin producing ?-cells [ 17 18 19 ] , resulting in the production of oxygen-derived free radicals that induce DNA-damage and apoptosis in both rodent and human ?-cells [ 20 21 22 23 24 25 ] . In both type 1 and type 1, as well as, type 2 diabetes, the role of free radicals in diabetic complications is well studied.
In that study, an increased number of cells with DNA damage correlated with a decreased ?-cell mass [ 32 ] .

Moreover, it is possible that ?-cells from patients with longstanding diabetes have a higher threshold for an apoptotic response to DNA-damage than ?-cells in normal subjects, as it has been shown that this threshold increases with age [ 43 ] . Consequently, ?-cells with high levels of DNA damage from younger individuals with a shorter duration of diabetes might be eliminated by apoptosis, while similarly damaged ?-cells from older individuals, who are likely to have had diabetes for a longer time may be resistant to apoptosis and so remain.
